content: [4]In 2009, thegroup of Cooper demonstrated that [6+4] cages, synthesizedby 12-fold imine condensation of 1,3,5-triformylbenzeneand chiral diamines, could be freed from enclathrated solv-ate molecules in the crystalline state to give materials withspecific surface areas of 624 m2g每1, according to theBrunauer每Emmett每Teller model.[5]Since then, this new re-search area has been developing very quickly,[6]and besidesimine condensation reactions[7每9]other types of reversiblereactions, such as that of boronic acids and diols, have beenapplied to synthesize shape-persistent organic cages thatcan be used to create porous materials with mesopores andspecific surface areas of 3758 m2g每1.[10]Still, one of the most porous cages with a very high sur-face area of 2071 m2g每1is based on the [4+6] condensation[a] Organisch-Chemisches-Institut, Ruprecht-Karls-Universit?tHeidelberg,Im Neuenheimer Feld 273, 69120 Heidelberg, GermanyE-mail: Michael.Mastalerz@oci.uni-heidelberg.dehttp://www.uni-heidelberg.de/fakultaeten/chemgeo/oci/mastalerz/index.htmlSupporting information for this article is available on theWWW under http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/ejoc.201500228.

[38]Triaminotriptycene ( 9) was synthesized according tothe protocol of Zhang and Chen.[40]For thin-layer chromatography,Silica gel 60 F 254plates from Merck were used, which were exam-ined under UV-light irradiation (254 and 365 nm). Flash columnchromatography was performed on silica gel from Sigma每Aldrich(particle size: 0.04每0.063 mm) by using petroleum ether, ethyl acet-ate, and glacial acetic acid. Melting points (not corrected) weremeasured with a B邦chi Melting Point B-540 device. IR spectra wererecorded with a Bruker Lumos spectrometer by using a Ge ATRcrystal. NMR spectra were taken with a Bruker Avance III 600(1H NMR: 600 MHz,13C NMR: 151 MHz), Avance III 500(1H NMR: 500 MHz,13C NMR: 125 MHz), Avance III 400(1H NMR: 400 MHz,13C NMR: 100 MHz), Avance DRX 300 andAvance III 300 (1H NMR: 300 MHz,13C NMR: 75 MHz) spec-trometers at 298 K, unless otherwise mentioned. Chemical shifts(汛) are reported relative to trace amounts of CHCl3(汛H= 7.26 ppm,汛C= 77.0 ppm), DMSO ( 汛H= 2.50 ppm, 汛C= 39.5 ppm), or tetra-chloroethane ( 汛H= 5.96 ppm, 汛C= 73.8 ppm) in the correspondingdeuterated solvent. HRMS (ESI) as well as HRMS (MALDI) ex-periments were performed with a Fourier Transform Ion CyclotronResonance (FT-ICR) mass spectrometer Bruker ApexQe hybrid9.4 T FT-ICR equipped with a 9.4 T superconducting magnet and 10990690, 2015, 15, Downloaded from https://chemistry-europe.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ejoc.201500228 by Zhejiang University, Wiley Online Library on [24/07/2023]. Mastalerz FULL PAPERinterfaced to an Apollo II MTP Dual ESI/MALDI source, whereasHRMS (EI+) spectra were recorded under usage of a JEOL JMS-700 Magnetic Sector Instrument. MALDI mass spectra were mea-sured in positive mode with DCTB as matrix. Elemental analysiswas performed by the Microanalytical Laboratory of the Universityof Heidelberg by using an Elementar Vario Micro Cube. Crystalstructure analysis was accomplished with a Bruker APEX-II Qua-zar diffractometer with a molybdenum source [ 竹(MoK汐=0.71073 ?].[41]CCDC-1049101 (for 4d) and -1049102 (for 6) contain the supple-mentary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can beobtained free of charge from The Cambridge CrystallographicData Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

First, route A was investigated. It started with the syn-thesis of 4-bromosalicyldialdehyde ( 2), which was achievedin about 35% yield by twofold Duff formylation by usingHMTA (2.3 equiv.) and TFA (solvent) as the reactants at100 ∼C for 24 h according to the method of Svenstrup et al.,as previously reported.
[14]A more recent publication de-scribes a slightly different protocol, for which under harsherconditions (110 ∼C, 48 h, 20 equiv. HMTA) 2can be iso-lated in 92% yield.

dialdehyde 4j. Upon applying the standard conditions(4 equiv. HMTA, 100 ∼C, 3 days), 5jwas diformylated in10% yield to give 4jin addition to 70 % of monoaldehyde7j(Table 2, entry 1). By using higher temperatures (4 equiv.

HMTA, 125 ∼C), the yield of desired twofold formylatedproduct 4jincreased to 27% (Table 2, entry 2); by doublingthe amount of HMTA to 8 equiv., the yield was slightlyraised to 35% (Table 2, entry 3). For 5i, we observed aneven larger effect upon using harsher conditions, and theEur. J. Org. Chem. 2015 , 3274每3285 ? 2015 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.eurjoc.org 3277yield of the diformylated product increased from 25 to 73%(Table 2, entries 4 and 5). Nitro compound 4kwas isolatedin 33 % yield beside 30% of monoaldehyde 7k. Even penta-fluorophenyl-substituted salicyldialdehyde 4lwas accessiblein 57% yield (Table 2, entry 7), which could not be realizedat all by route A.
Scheme 4. Duff formylation of electron-poor substituted 4-hydroxybiphenyls as the second step of route B. For conditions andyields, see Table 2.

If5gwithout an electron-donating or electron-with-drawing group was treated with a slight excess amount ofHMTA (2.1 equiv.) for 3 h at 100 ∼C, monoformylatedproduct 7gdominated with a yield of 74 % besides 4% of4g. By using 6 equiv. of HMTA (Table 2, entry 9) 4gwasthen again isolated in 49% yield besides 13% yield of themonoaldehyde. ?kermark has previously reported that 4gcan be synthesized in 92 % yield by using 20 equiv. ofHMTA.

4-Bromo-2,6-diformylphenol (2): 4-Bromophenol ( 1; 13.5 g,70.0 mmol) and HMTA (22.3 g, 160 mmol) were dissolved in an-hydrous TFA (100 mL), and the mixture was heated to 100 ∼C for24 h under an argon atmosphere. After cooling to room tempera-ture, the brownish solution was poured into 4 mHCl and left tocrystallize overnight. The yellow crystalline solid was filtered off,dried in vacuo, and purified by flash column chromatography onsilica gel (light petroleum ether/CH2Cl2, 5:2) to give two fractions.

First fraction ( Rf= 0.40): monoaldehyde (3.71 g, 25 %), white solid;m.p. 104 ∼C.1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl 3):汛= 10.93 (s, -O H), 9.85(s, -C HO), 7.68 (d,4J= 2.5 Hz, H-3), 7.61 (dd,3J= 8.9 Hz,4J=2.5 Hz, H-5), 6.91 ppm (d,3J= 8.9 Hz, H-6) ppm. Second fraction(Rf= 0.13): Dialdehyde 2(5.86 g, 35 %), pale yellow crystallinesolid; m.p. 139 ∼C.1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl 3):汛= 11.54 (s, 1H, -O H), 10.19 (s, 2 H, -C HO), 8.06 ppm (s, 2 H, 3,5-H). Theanalytical data are in accordance with those previously pub-lished.
[14,23]Alternative Procedure:[23]Compound 1(1.47 g, 8.50 mmol) andHMTA (9.52 g, 67.9 mmol) were dissolved in anhydrousCF3COOH (25 mL), and the mixture was heated at 110 ∼C for 48 h.

After cooling to room temperature, the mixture was poured into4mHCl (50 mL) and stirred for 5 h. The yellow solid was filteredoff and washed with H2O( 3/H1100315 mL). Purification by flash col-umn chromatography on silica gel (light petroleum ether/CH 2Cl2,5:2) gave, after drying in vacuo, 2(1.01 g, 52 %). The analytical dataare in accordance with those previously published.[14,23]General Procedure for the Synthesis of Electron-Rich Salicyldi-aldehydes by Suzuki每Miyaura Cross-Coupling (GP1): 4-Bromo-2,6-diformylphenol ( 2, 1 equiv.) and arylboronic acid 3(1.1 equiv.)were dissolved in THF and mixed with a solution of KF (3 equiv.)in H2O under an argon atmosphere. Pd 2(dba) 3(0.5每1.0 mol-%) andHP(tBu) 3BF 4(1.0每2.0 mol-%) were added, and the mixture washeated for 16 h at 70每80 ∼C. After cooling to room temperature,the resulting mixture was quenched with satd. aq. NH4Cl (20 mL)and extracted with THF (3 /H1100320 mL). The combined organic layerwas washed with brine and dried with MgSO 4. After removal ofthe solvent under reduced pressure, the crude product was purifiedby flash column chromatography and dried in vacuo to give thedesired dialdehyde.

4-Hydroxy-4 /H11032-methoxy-1,1 /H11032-biphenyl-3,5-dicarbaldehyde (4a):According to GP1, 2(229 mg, 1.00 mmol) and (4-methoxyphenyl)-boronic acid ( 3a; 167 mg, 1.10 mmol) were dissolved in THF(2 mL) and mixed with a solution of KF (174 mg, 3.00 mmol) inH2O (0.7 mL) under an argon atmosphere. Pd 2(dba) 3(4.6 mg,0.005 mmol) and HP( tBu) 3BF 4(5.8 mg, 0.02 mmol) were added,and the mixture was stirred for 16 h at 80 ∼C. After workup andflash column chromatography on silica gel (light petroleum ether/EtOAc, 9:1 to 7:1), 4awas obtained as a yellow solid (220 mg,86 %); m.p. 131 ∼C.

4/H11032-tert-Butyl-4-hydroxy-1,1 /H11032-biphenyl-3,5-dicarbaldehyde (4b):According to GP1, 2(229 mg, 1.00 mmol) and (4- tert-butylphenyl)-boronic acid ( 3b; 196 mg, 1.10 mmol) were dissolved in THF(2 mL) and mixed with a solution of KF (174 mg, 3.00 mmol) inH2O (0.7 mL) under an argon atmosphere. Pd 2(dba) 3(9.5 mg,0.01 mmol) and HP( tBu) 3BF 4(11.0 mg, 0.04 mmol) were added,and the mixture was stirred for 16 h at 80 ∼C. After workup andflash column chromatography on silica gel (light petroleum ether/EtOAc, 20:1), 4bwas obtained as a yellow solid (231 mg, 82 %);m.p. 97每98 ∼C.

4-(5/H11032-Hexylthiophen-2 /H11032-yl)-2-hydroxy-1,3-benzenedicarbaldehyde(4c): According to GP1, 2(229 mg, 1.00 mmol) and (5-hexylthi-enyl)boronic ester ( 3c; 324 mg, 1.10 mmol) were dissolved in THF(2.0 mL) and mixed with a solution of KF (174 mg, 3.00 mmol)in H2O (0.7 mL) under an argon atmosphere. Pd 2(dba) 3(4.5 mg,0.005 mmol) and HP( tBu) 3BF 4(5.8 mg, 0.02 mmol) were added,and the mixture was stirred for 16 h at 80 ∼C After workup andflash column chromatography on silica gel (light petroleum ether/EtOAc, 20:1), 4cwas obtained as a yellow waxy solid (214 mg,68 %); m.p. 63 ∼C.

Pd 2(dba) 3(18.3 mg, 0.02 mmol) andHP(tBu) 3BF 4(23.2 mg, 0.08 mmol) were added, and the mixturewas stirred for 16 h at 80 ∼C. After workup and flash columnchromatography on silica gel (light petroleum ether/EtOAc, 20:1),4dwas obtained as a yellow solid (608 mg, 93 %); m.p. 165 ∼C(dec.).

4,4/H11032-Dihydroxy-1,1 /H11032-biphenyl-3,5-dicarbaldehyde (4e): According toGP, 2(143 mg, 0.62 mmol, 1.00 equiv.) and (4-hydroxyphenyl)bo-ronic acid ( 3e; 95.0 mg, 0.69 mmol, 1.10 equiv.) were dissolved inTHF (1.5 mL) and mixed with an aq. K 2CO 3solution (1 m,0.7 mL) under an argon atmosphere. Pd 2(dba) 3(10 mg, 0.01 mmol)and HP( tBu) 3BF 4(10 mg, 0.04 mmol) were added, and the mixturewas stirred for 16 h at 80 ∼C. After workup and flash columnchromatography on silica gel (light petroleum ether/EtOAc, 20:1),4ewas obtained as an orange solid (73 mg, 0.32 mmol, 52 %); m.p.

4-Hydroxy-3 /H11032,5/H11032-dimethoxy-1,1 /H11032-biphenyl-3,5-dicarbaldehyde (4f):According to GP, 2(229 mg, 1.00 mmol) and (3,5-dimeth-oxyphenyl)boronic acid ( 3f; 200 mg, 1.10 mmol) were dissolved inTHF (2 mL) and mixed with a solution of KF (174 mg, 3.00 mmol)in H2O (0.7 mL) under an argon atmosphere. Pd 2(dba) 3(9.5 mg,0.01 mmol) and HP( tBu) 3BF 4(11.0 mg, 0.04 mmol) were added,and the mixture was stirred for 16 h at 80 ∼C. After workup andflash column chromatography on silica gel (light petroleum ether/EtOAc, 9:1 to 6:1), 4fwas obtained as a yellow solid (121 mg,0.42 mmol, 43 %); m.p. 175 ∼C.

4-Hydroxy-1,1 /H11032-biphenyl-3,5-dicarbaldehyde (4g): According to GP,2(229 mg, 1.00 mmol) and phenylboronic acid ( 3g; 134 mg,1.10 mmol) were dissolved in THF (1.3 mL) and mixed with a solu-tion of KF (174 mg, 3.00 mmol) in H2O (0.7 mL) under an argonatmosphere. Pd 2(dba) 3(4.6 mg, 0.005 mmol) and HP( tBu) 3BF 4(5.8 mg, 0.02 mmol) were added, and the mixture was stirred for16 h at 80 ∼C. After workup and column chromatography on silicagel (light petroleum ether/EtOAc/HOAc, 95:4:1), 4gwas obtainedas a pale yellow solid (77 mg, 34 %); m.p. 112 ∼C.

[41]4-Hydroxy-1,1 /H11032-biphenyl-3,5,4 /H11032-tricarbaldehyde (4h): According toGP, 2(229 mg, 1.00 mmol) and (4-formylphenyl)boronic acid ( 3h;165 mg, 1.10 mmol) were dissolved in THF (2 mL) and mixed witha solution of KF (174 mg, 3.00 mmol) in H2O (0.7 mL) under anargon atmosphere. After the addition of Pd 2(dba) 3(4.6 mg,0.005 mmol) and HP( tBu) 3BF 4(5.9 mg, 0.02 mmol), the mixturewas stirred for 16 h at 80 ∼C. After workup and flash columnchromatography on silica gel (light petroleum ether/EtOAc, 7:1 to2:1), 4hwas obtained as an off-white solid (87 mg, 0.34 mmol,34 %); m.p. 176 ∼C.

General Procedure for the Synthesis of Electron-Poor Salicyldi-aldehydes by Suzuki每Miyaura Cross-Coupling (GP2): 4-Bromo-2,6-diformylphenol ( 2, 1 equiv.), arylboronic acid 3(1.1 equiv.), andK2CO 3(3 equiv.) were suspended in DME/H 2O (1:1 v/v) under anargon atmosphere. Pd(OAc) 2and PPh 3were added, and the mix-ture was stirred for 16 h at 105 ∼C. The reaction was quenched bythe addition of satd. aq. NH4Cl (20 mL) followed by extractionwith EtOAc (3 /H1100350 mL). The organic extract was washed withbrine and dried with MgSO 4, and the solvent was removed underreduced pressure to give the crude product as a yellow to orangeresidue. Purification by flash column chromatography gave thebiaryl.

4-Hydroxy-4 /H11032-methyloxycarbonyl-1,1 /H11032-biphenyl-3,5-dicarbaldehyde(4j): According to GP2, 2(229 mg, 1.00 mmol), (4-methoxycarb-onylphenyl)boronic acid ( 3j; 198 mg, 1.10 mmol), and K 2CO 3(415 mg, 3.00 mmol) were suspended in DME/H 2O( 1 : 1 v/v,2.4 mL) under an argon atmosphere. After the addition of Pd-(OAc)2(4.5 mg, 0.02 mmol) and PPh 3(10.5 mg, 0.04 mmol), themixture was stirred for 16 h at 105 ∼C. After workup, purificationby flash column chromatography on silica gel (light petroleumether/EtOAc, 8:1 to 3:2) gave 4jas an off-white solid (87 mg, 31 %);m.p. 190 ∼C.

4-Hydroxy-4 /H11032-nitro-1,1 /H11032-biphenyl-3,5-dicarbaldehyde (4k): Accord-ing to GP2, 2(229 mg, 1.00 mmol), (4-nitrophenyl)boronic acid(3k; 184 mg, 1.10 mmol), and K 2CO 3(415 mg, 3.00 mmol) weresuspended in DME/H 2O (1:1 v/v, 2.4 mL) under an argon atmo-sphere. After the addition of Pd(OAc) 2(4.5 mg, 0.02 mmol) andPPh 3(10.5 mg, 0.04 mmol), the mixture was sti rred for 16 h at105 ∼C. After workup, purification by flash column chromatog-raphy on silica gel (light petroleum ether/EtOAc, 5:1 to 3:2) gave 4kas a pale yellow solid (78 mg, 29 %); m.p. 241 ∼C (dec.).

General Procedure for Duff Formylation of 4-Arylsubstituted Phen-ols (GP3): 4-Hydroxybiphenyl 5(1 equiv.) and hexamethylenetetra-mine (HMTA, 4每8 equiv.) were dissolved under an argon atmo-sphere in anhydrous trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), and the mixturewas stirred at 100每125 ∼C in a closed vessel for 16每72 h. The darkyellow to brownish solution was cooled to room temperature andpoured into a mixture of 4 mHCl/CH2Cl2(1:1v/v). The resultingmixture was vigorously stirred for 4 h at room temperature. Thelayers were separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted withCH2Cl2(2/H11003). The combined extract was washed with H 2O andbrine and dried with MgSO 4. The crude product was obtained asa yellow residue after solvent removal under reduced pressure andwas purified by flash column chromatography to give, after dryingin vacuo, the formylated products.

4-Hydroxy-4 /H11032-methoxy-1,1 /H11032-biphenyl-3,3 /H11032-dicarbaldehyde (8): Ac-cording to GP3, 4-(4 /H11032-methoxyphenyl)phenol ( 5a; 100 mg,0.50 mmol) was treated with HMTA (154 mg, 1.00 mmol) in TFA(1.1 mL) and stirred for 3 h at 100 ∼C. After workup, the crudeproduct was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel(light petroleum ether/EtOAc, 4:1; Rf= 0.25) to give dicarb-aldehyde 8(43 mg, 33 %) as an off-white solid; m.p. 114 ∼C.1HNMR (400 MHz, CDCl 3):汛= 10.99 (s, 1 H, -O H), 10.53 (s, 1 H, -CH/H11032O), 9.98 (s, 1 H, -C HO), 8.04 (d,4J= 2.5 Hz, 1 H, 2 /H11032-H), 7.78每7.73 (m, 3 H, 2,6,6 /H11032-H), 7.11每7.08 (m, 1 H, 5 /H11032-H), 7.09每7.06 (m, 1H, 5-H), 3.99 ppm (s, 3 H, -OC H3).13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl 3):汛= 196.7 (- CHO), 189.7 (- C/H11032HO), 161.5 ( C-4/H11032), 161.2 ( C-4), 135.4(C-6), 133.8 ( C-6/H11032), 132.2 ( C-1/H11032), 131.9 ( C-1), 131.6 ( C-2), 126.4 ( C-2/H11032), 125.3 ( C-3/H11032), 121.0 ( C-3), 118.5 ( C-5), 112.6 ( C-5/H11032), 56.08 ppm(-OCH3). HRMS (ESI): calcd. for C 15H11O4[ M每H ]每255.06628;found 255.06586; 忖= 每0.9 ppm. Analytical data are in accordancewith those previously published.[42]4-Hydroxy-3 /H11032,5/H11032-bis(trifluoromethyl)-1,1 /H11032-biphenyl-3,5-dicarbalde-hyde (4i) and 4-Hydroxy-3 /H11032,5/H11032-bis(trifluorome thyl)-1,1 /H11032-biphenyl-3-carbaldehyde (7i): According to GP3, 4-hydroxy-3 /H11032,5/H11032-bis(trifluoro-methyl)-1,1 /H11032-biphenyl ( 3i; 100 mg, 0.33 mmol) was treated withHMTA (183 mg, 1.31 mmol) in TFA (1.5 mL) and heated for 72 hat 105 ∼C. Chem.  2015  ﹞ ISSN 1099 每0682   SUPPORTING INFORMATION   DOI:  10.1002/ejoc.201500228  Title:  Synthesis of para -Aryl-Substituted Salicyldialdehydes  Author(s):  Denni s Reinhard,  Ludger Sch?ttner,  Victor Brosius,  Frank Rominger,  Michael Mastalerz*

ofpara-substituted salicyldialdehydes with triptycenetriamine.[8a]This [4+6] cage has been used for further trans-formations in the interiors of cavities[11]and as a solubleporous unit to decorate quartz microcrystal balances withthin films of these cages to create gravimetric sensors forairborne analytes.
[12]For these [4+6] cages it has been dem-onstrated that the peripheral substituents have a significantimpact on the crystal packing and, thus, the accessible sur-face areas.

[14]It is known for cage compounds that aromatic moietiesin the periphery can influence the packing of cages in thecrystalline state by 羽每羽stacking, and therefore, salicyldi-aldehydes that are para-substituted with an aromatic unitwould be desired as molecular building blocks for the con-struction of [4+6] cages.

[15]Considering that salicyldi-aldehydes are used for the synthesis of [4+6] cages, larger[8+12] cages,[16]water-soluble fluorescent dyes,[17]spiro-benzopyrans as sensors,[18]homooxacalixarenes,[19]smallermacrocycles as ligands for dinuclear metal complexes,[20]larger macrocycles,[21]and cryptands,[22]it is surprising thatthere is no general protocol for the synthesis of para-aryl-substituted salicyldialdehydes.[23]Herein, we describe thedevelopment of two synthetic routes to make a variety ofpara-aryl-substituted salicyldialdehydes readily available.Synthesis of para-Aryl-Substituted SalicyldialdehydesResults and DiscussionThe formylation of phenols by the procedure first investi-gated by Duff and Bills is a useful method to synthesizesalicylaldehydes.
Preliminary tests for the use of the new dialdehydes inthe synthesis of [4+6] cages were performed (Scheme 6).

The new aryl-substituted salicyldialdehydes are versatileprecursors for imine cages. Indeed, preliminary results onthe reaction of anthracenyl-substituted salicyldialdehyde 4dwith triamine 9showed the formation of correspondingcage 10. With the herein presented methods, a variety ofnew salicyldialdehydes can be obtained, which will be usedEur. J. Org. Chem. 2015 , 3274每3285 ? 2015 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim www.eurjoc.org 3279by us to enlarge the family of periphery-substituted [4+6]imine cages. Besides that, these are versatile precursors forfluorescent dyes, new homooxacalixarenes, spiropyrans, andmacrocycles.
